Ministers were given the latest information in regard too operations in Holland and Belgium.Discussion ensued as to the prospects of a German thrustreaching the Dyle line before our forces had succeeded in establishing themselves.Reference was also made to the air action which had been takento hinder the German advance in the break of the Belgian lineopposite Maastricht. Two messages from Sir Roger Keyes on thismatter were read out. The Chief of the Air Staff said that theCommander-in-Chief of the Air Striking Force in France had saidthat he had complied with all the requests made on him, with one exception, when he had felt that it was right to attack some othertarget.In connection with operations in Holland, Ministers were informed that a composite Guards Battalion of 700 or 800 strongwas being prepared, which could be sent next day (12th May) via the Hook of Holland to assist the Dutch in clearing up the positionround The Hague and Rotterdam.It was decided to leave it to the discretion of the Chiefs ofStaff, at their morning Meeting, to settle whether this force shouldbe despatched to Holland.Reference was made to the decision reached that morning thatthe Armoured Division should proceed to France. It was explainedthat the brigades were self-contained, and would proceed one at atime; i.e., it would be feasible, if so desired, to retain the secondbrigade in this country, although the first brigade had gone toFrance.Some anxiety was felt lest the very large supplies of oil now in holland should fall into the enemy's hands.The Secretary of State for Foreign A ffairs was invited to send a telegram to our Minister at The Hague inviting him to impress on the Dutch authorities the vital importance of destroying oil supplies before the enemy could seize them.Norway.Progress of operations:Bodo-Mo area.(previous reference:W.M. (40) 342) were read atthe Meeting. These telegrams dealt with the question of the policy to be pursued in regard to the Bodo-Mo-Mosjoen area, havingregard to the possibility that, if the enemy seized this area, theymight establish aerodromes in it.A reply to the telegram of the 10th May was read to theMeeting and its despatch was approved (Copy annexed).Reference was also made to the landing of a party of 600Germans at Hemnes, near Mo.A battalion of the Scots Guards had been sent from Narvik,in ships, to proceed to Mo or Bodo.The First Sea Lord said that he had despatched a telegram to the F.O. Narvik, saying that he was not aware what orders had been given to this force, but emphasising the importance ofcleaning up the German force near Mo, if possible.The line set out in this telegram met with strong approval.Invasion of 3. The Secretary- of State for Foreign Affairs referred to aStates of suggestion which he had made at an earlier date, that we might askAmerica. the United States authorities to let us have aircraft at once fromSupplies of their own supplies, on the understanding that we should replaceaircraft. these aircraft later from the orders which had already been placedon account of the British Government with manufacturers in theUnited States.It was agreed that the Air Ministry should be invited tosupply material to the Foreign Office for a telegram to theUnited States Government putting forward thissuggestion.Richmond Terrace, S.W. 1,May 11, 1940.ANNEX.Telegram to Lord Cork in reply to his Telegram No. 1531, dated May 10.THE military advantages of the Bodo area to us and the importance ofdenying them to the enemy are fully recognised. Our policy outlined in our telegram 1910/5 remains the same, except that we must now make it clear that,in view of the present situation, you cannot expect any further anti-aircraft orfighter reinforcements over and above those already authorised. In fact, itis probable that you will receive no more than the 48 heavy and 60 light a.A. guns now with you or on the way. It must also be clear that it will notbe possible to run separate convoys from the United Kingdom for the maintenanceof forces in the Bodo-Mo-Mosjoen area; these forces must be supplied by youby trawlers or other small craft from Narvik.[Handed by Colonel Hollis to First Sea Lord's Secretary for despatch at0010 hrs. the 12th May.]
